profileText: A Delegate from Pennsylvania; born at West River, Anne Arundel County, Md., 1731; moved with his father to Pennsylvania in 1740; received a liberal schooling; studied law; was admitted to the bar and began practice in Philadelphia, Pa.; member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives 1757-1775, and served as speaker 1766-1774; Member of the Continental Congress in 1774; signed the nonimportation agreement, but was opposed to independence of the Colonies and remained loyal to the King; in December 1776 joined the British Army of General Howe in New York; moved to England in 1778; the same year the General Assembly of Pennsylvania convicted him of high treason and confiscated his estates; died in Watford, Herts, England, August 29, 1803.

researchRecord.name: In the Joseph Galloway Family Papers, 1743-1823, 0.4 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: The papers include chiefly family correspondence of James Galloway, his wife, Grace (Growden) Galloway, their daughter, Elizabeth, and Mrs. Galloway's brother, Thomas Nickelson, of Dorset, England. The collection also contains a travel notebook and letters of James Galloway to his wife, verses written and collected by Grace Galloway, together with letters describing her trials as a Loyalist wife during the American Revolution; and correspondence of Elizabeth with English friends.

researchRecord.name: In the Peter Force Collection, 1779-1785, 5 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers contain a printed volume entitled The Examination of Joseph Galloway...Before the House of Commons (London, 1779) with marginal notations by Israel Mauduit and a news clipping. Also included is a volume with 2 drafts (no date) of a letter to Gen. John Burgoyne relating to Burgoyne's conduct and activities during the American Revolution; a draft (no date) of a letter to Lord [Richard Howe?] regarding British treatment of the Loyalists; and a draft (ca. 1785) of James Galloway's Plan of Union. A finding aid is available in the Manuscript Reading Room.

researchRecord.name: In the Benjamin Franklin Papers, 1770, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Benjamin Franklin to Joseph Galloway written on March 21, 1770. In the letter, Benjamin Franklin analyzes the attitude of the British Parliament and Cabinet toward the American colonies' non-importation agreement, urges the colonies to hold fast to the agreement, and encourages the development of local manufactures.
